content.webTitle: The Bodyguard review – a shallow, shaky love story with all the thrills of a wet sock

fields.headline: The Bodyguard review – a shallow, shaky love story with all the thrills of a wet sock
fields.bodyText: There’s a moment in The Bodyguard when even the most sceptical of romantics might swoon. In the midst of dangerous chaos unleashed during a concert, security man Frank Farmer – the strong, silent type fond of weighty stares – rescues pop star Rachel Marron. Sweeping her in his arms, he carries her to safety – and into his heart. It was a classic scene in the 1992 blockbuster movie starring Whitney Houston and Kevin Costner. Not so in this remake for the stage, conceived in London’s West End and now playing in Sydney with an Australian cast. Frank’s rescue is more effete than Herculean and the danger facing Rachel is so flaccid I missed it entirely. No amount of strobe lighting can save what must be this musical’s Big Moment. In fact, no strobe lighting, live flames, streamers, or confetti (all used amply in a glitzy but hollow production) can save The Bodyguard, full stop. Screenwriter Alexander Dinelaris, known for Birdman, has strung together an already shallow and shaky love story with a heightened thriller plot that has all the scares of a wet sock. We know the story: stalker threatens star, star hires bodyguard, bodyguard rescues star, star falls for bodyguard. Beyond this, the rest is simply confusing. I’m not quite sure why Rachel invites her envious sister Nicki (Prinnie Stevens) to gawp at Frank, postcoital and naked in her bed, or why he doesn’t wake up with two squabbling women talking over him. Nor why a hard-hitting bodyguard facing a trained killer would whisk Rachel away to his family home – surely the first place any respectable stalker would think to look? When the stalker finally bursts in with a giant butcher’s knife, a woman near me snorted out loud. The Bodyguard’s saving grace is the Fijian-born singer-songwriter Paulini Curuenavuli, of Australian Idol fame, who plays Rachel. It’s true that Paulini, as she’s known, can’t act. And her American accent, like the rest of the cast, is appalling. And she seems to have trouble remembering her lines. But she has one hell of a voice. The same can’t be said of soap star Kip Gamblin, who only has one real task: to sweep the audience off its feet. He fails. Faced with what is admittedly a razor-thin script, Gamblin compensates with leaden pauses and self-conscious pouting. Combined with a wooden delivery of lines, it’s no wonder that the lovers have zero chemistry. A kiss between Frank and Rachel, broadcast in epic scale onto a giant screen, is just, well, slurpy. The Bodyguard film spawned one of the best-selling soundtracks of all time and the 16 of Whitney Houston’s hits on offer here will fill seats alone. For those who aren’t diehard fans, though, do yourself a favour: skip this spineless musical, a cynical exercise in moneymaking, and buy the DVD instead. • The Bodyguard is playing at the Sydney Lyric theatre from 21 April, Brisbane Lyric theatre from 19 July and Melbourne’s Regent theatre from 24 August
